items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are slowly falling on sections of the River Churn following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are falling on the lower River Cherwell. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue in the Thrupp area. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect river levels to continue falling, but will remain high and out of banks into next week.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Windrush. The flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially around Bourton-on-the-Water and near the confluence with the River Thames. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. Water levels will remain high over the next few days. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are normal on the River Evenlode but remain high on the River Glyme. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today along the River Glyme in the Woodstock area. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. Levels on the River Glyme are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. River levels remain high but are falling. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, especially in the Abingdon area. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect river levels to continue falling over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but within banks on the Ginge Brook. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We do not expect to see any rises in water levels over the next few days, however the brook remains sensitive to rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are falling on the River Ray. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Islip area. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect river levels to continue falling, but will remain high and out of banks near Islip into next week. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels along the River Thame are falling. Levels remain high in the lower reaches and flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect water to remain out of banks over the next few days.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Avon and its tributaries. High ground water will keep river levels high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
The forecast is for no significant rain in the next 24 hours.
We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high within the Hundred Foot Washes. This information is correct as of 3:30 pm on Sunday 15th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 24 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 37 centimetres of water on the road. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Monday 16th December 2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but remain high on the Lower Colne, Sunday 15th December.
Flooding to low lying land and roads may continue to affect locations near the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, Poyle Channel, Staines Moor and Longford.
The forecast is mostly dry but the levels on the Lower River Colne are expected to remain high for several days. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 10am Monday 16th December, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Tern – Walcot river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
Showers are possible today but rainfall is not forecast to be significant. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Monday, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but flowing within banks on the River Dikler. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling today.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but flowing within banks on the  River Leach. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight. River levels are expected to continue falling over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are now starting to fall slowly on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall last week. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall  slowly.  We will continue to monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene due to recent heavy rainfall. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated on Monday 16th December, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Darragh. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
Showers are possible today but rainfall is not forecast to be significant. River levels are falling slowly, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Monday, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.60m and is steady. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.06m and is falling. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m and the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m. The roads from Muchelney to Thorney and from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, are not affected. Property flooding at this time is not expected.

Dry weather is forecast for the rest of today and tomorrow, with rain forecast Tuesday. We will continue to pump water from the moors during this dry spell.

We will continue to monitor the situation, clearing weed screens and checking rivers for blockages. Don't put yourself or others at risk. For further details, please search for Somerset emergency road closure. This message will be updated by 2PM on 16/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message: River levels remain high but are falling on the Leigh Brook river gauge near Leigh Court following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Wainlode Lane. Observed peaks: Tewkesbury Upper Pound 4.11m 11/12/24 and Mythe 4.12m 11/12/2024. No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. However, we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6pm on Monday, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message:
River levels remain high due to the rainfall associated with Storm Darragh. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Thornton Lock, Stamford Bridge, Buttercrambe and Elvington.
 
No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to fall slowly over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Sunday 15/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message:
River levels remain high in response to the rainfall associated with Storm Darragh. Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent area, including the low lying land around the Low Marishes, Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton. 

No further significant rainfall is expected in the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. The flood warning for Old Malton has been removed and pumping operations continue in Malton. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Sunday 15/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible between 5:45 AM and 6:30 AM on 16/12/2024.
Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point .
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
Higher than normal tides and strong winds are forecast tomorrow morning and may lead to flooding.

The tide is expected to be at its highest between 3:00AM and 3:30AM tomorrow morning (Monday, 16/12/2024). Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time.

Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths particularly in the Newcastle Quayside area. Property flooding is not expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Be careful along riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible between 5:15 AM and 7:15AM on 16/12/2024.
Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for no further rainfall and we expect levels to stabilise and then recede

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and groundwater levels are predicted to level off soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high, but are now slowly dropping. Increased ground water is keeping levels high in some areas.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
The forecast for the next 24 hours is for no further significant rain.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to slowly rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. No further rainfall is expected and we expect groundwater levels to stop rising soon.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 17/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Coln and tributaries. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is still expected in the Fossebridge area. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling over the next few days. Today, 15/12/2024, is forecast to be mainly dry followed by light rain in places overnight.
We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Little Ouse River and River Thet in Suffolk and Norfolk
Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue to rise over the coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore  be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of persistent rainfall. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to rise over coming weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 17/12/2024 or as the situation changes.
